quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 4)
quiz.subtitle: 3.4 Normal vs Inferior Goods: Income Effects on Demand (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Normal Goods, Inferior Goods, Income Elasticity, Consumer Behavior

questions.question: A normal good is defined as a good for which:
options: Demand decreases when consumer income increases
Demand increases when consumer income increases
Demand remains constant regardless of income changes
Price and quantity demanded are inversely related
questions.explanation: Normal goods are those for which demand increases when consumer income rises, and decreases when income falls, holding all other factors constant.

questions.question: An inferior good is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Inferior goods are those for which demand decreases when consumer income rises, as consumers switch to higher-quality alternatives.

questions.question: If consumer income increases and demand for a product increases, the product is:
questions.explanation: When demand increases with rising income, the product is a normal good. This includes both necessities and luxury goods.

questions.question: Which of the following is typically considered an inferior good?
questions.explanation: Public transportation is often an inferior good because as incomes rise, people tend to switch to private cars or taxis instead of buses or subways.

questions.question: During an economic recession when incomes fall, demand for inferior goods typically:
questions.explanation: When incomes fall, consumers switch from normal goods to cheaper inferior alternatives, increasing demand for inferior goods.

questions.question: Luxury goods are a special category of normal goods characterized by:
questions.explanation: Luxury goods have income elasticity greater than 1, meaning demand increases more than proportionally to income increases.

questions.question: If a family's income doubles and their consumption of generic brand groceries decreases while name-brand groceries increase, generic brands are:
questions.explanation: The decrease in demand for generic brands when income rises indicates they are inferior goods, as consumers switch to higher-quality name brands.

questions.question: For a normal good, an increase in consumer income will cause the demand curve to:
questions.explanation: For normal goods, increased income leads to increased demand at every price level, shifting the demand curve to the right.

questions.question: For an inferior good, an increase in consumer income will cause the demand curve to:
questions.explanation: For inferior goods, increased income leads to decreased demand as consumers switch to better alternatives, shifting the demand curve to the left.

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely a normal good?
questions.explanation: Fine dining is a normal good because demand increases with income. The other options are more likely to be inferior goods where demand decreases as income rises.

questions.question: The income elasticity of demand measures:
options: How quantity demanded changes when price changes
How demand changes when income changes
How supply changes when costs change
How quantity supplied changes when price changes
questions.explanation: Income elasticity of demand measures the responsiveness of quantity demanded to changes in consumer income.

questions.question: A good with negative income elasticity is always:
questions.explanation: Negative income elasticity means demand decreases when income increases, which is the definition of an inferior good.

questions.question: During economic prosperity when incomes are rising, which type of business would likely see decreased demand?
questions.explanation: Thrift stores sell inferior goods - as incomes rise, consumers buy new clothing instead of used, decreasing demand for thrift store products.

questions.question: If income elasticity of demand is 0.5, the good is:
questions.explanation: Income elasticity between 0 and 1 indicates a normal necessity - demand increases with income but less than proportionally.

questions.question: The classification of a good as normal or inferior can change over time because:
questions.explanation: What consumers consider normal vs inferior can change with technology, social norms, and economic development. For example, mobile phones transitioned from luxury to necessity.

questions.question: If a good has income elasticity of 2.0, a 10% increase in income will cause demand to:
questions.explanation: Income elasticity of 2.0 means demand changes by 2% for every 1% change in income. A 10% income increase causes a 20% demand increase.

questions.question: Which statement about inferior goods is correct?
options: They are never purchased by wealthy consumers
questions.explanation: Inferior goods are defined by negative income elasticity, not necessarily low quality. Even high-quality goods can be inferior if consumers switch to even better alternatives as income rises.

questions.question: During an economic expansion, a company producing generic food products should expect:
questions.explanation: Generic food products are typically inferior goods. During economic expansions with rising incomes, consumers switch to name-brand products, decreasing demand for generics.

questions.question: A good can be normal for some consumers and inferior for others because:
options: Income elasticity depends on individual preferences and circumstances
questions.explanation: A good's classification depends on individual income levels and preferences. For example, bus transportation might be inferior for middle-income consumers but normal for very low-income consumers.

questions.question: The key difference between necessities and luxuries among normal goods is:
options: Necessities have income elasticity less than 1, luxuries greater than 1
Necessities are always cheaper than luxuries
questions.explanation: Necessities (0 < income elasticity < 1) see demand increase less than proportionally with income, while luxuries (income elasticity > 1) see demand increase more than proportionally.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong understanding of normal vs inferior goods and how income changes affect consumer demand patterns.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concepts but review the specific characteristics of luxury goods and how income elasticity determines good classification.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Normal goods = demand increases with income; Inferior goods = demand decreases with income; Luxuries have income elasticity > 1.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the key distinction: normal goods see demand rise with income, while inferior goods see demand fall with income.
